Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Engineering Safety-Critical Cyber-Physical-Human Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This cross-disciplinary project brings together a team of engineering and computer science researchers to create, validate, and demonstrate the value of new techniques for ensuring that systems composed of combinations of hardware, software, and humans are designed to operate in a truly synergistic and safe fashion. One notable and increasingly common feature of these "Cyber-Physical-Human" (CPH) systems is that the responsibility for safe operation and performance is typically shared by increasingly sophisticated automation in the form of hardware and software, and humans who direct and oversee the behavior of automation yet may need to intervene to take over manual or shared system control when unexpected environmental situations or hardware or software failures occur. The ultimate goal is to achieve levels of safety and performance in system operation that exceed the levels attainable by either skilled human operators or completely autonomous systems acting alone. To do so, the research team will draw upon their expertise in the design of robust, fault-tolerant control systems, in the design of complexity-reduction architectures for software verification, and in human factors techniques for cognitive modeling to assure high levels of human situation awareness through effective interface design. By doing so, the safety, cost and performance benefits of increasingly sophisticated automation can be achieved without the frequently observed safety risks caused by automation creating greater distance between human operators and system operation. The techniques will be iteratively created and empirically evaluated using experimentation in human-in-the-loop simulations, including a medium-fidelity aircraft and flight simulator and a simulation of assistive automation in a medical context.

More broadly, this research is expected to impact and inform the engineering of future CPH systems generally, for all industries and systems characterized by an increasing use of hardware and software automation directed and overseen by humans who provide an additional layer of safety in expected situations, Examples include highway and automotive automation, aerospace and air traffic control automation, semi-automated process control systems, and the many forms of automated systems and devices increasingly being used in medical contexts, such as the ICU and operating room. This research is also expected to inform government and industry efforts to provide safety certification criteria for the technologies used in CPH systems, and to educate a next generation of students trained in the cross-disciplinary skills and abilities needed to engineer the CPH systems of the future. The investigators will organize industry, academic, and government workshops to disseminate results and mentor students who are members of underrepresented groups through the course of this research project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In most safety-critical systems both humans and automation contribute to safe and efficient operation. Unfortunately, however, the problem of engineering the purely technological dimensions of such systems, that is, their cyber-physical components, does not typically include defining and supporting the human’s contribution to system safety in an essential and systematic fashion.  Engineering cyber-physical-human (CPH) systems requires that hardware and software automation design be tightly integrated with a human factors component devoted to supporting the human’s role in these systems. 

To achieve this goal, the research from this award includes: (i) the design and evaluation of robust fault-tolerant control systems yielding significantly enhanced levels of safety in highly unpredictable environments; and (ii) the design and implementation of complexity reduction architecture.

The developed RSimplex architecture includes a novel safety monitor, a high-performance controller (HPC), a robust high-assurance controller (RHAC), and a decision logic that triggers the switch between controllers. The safety monitor is used to detect physical failures only.  Based on this monitor, a monitor-based switching rule is introduced in the decision logic in addition to the traditional stability-envelope-based rule.  Experiments show that the integrated RSimplex can efficiently handle a class of software and physical failures.

Two types of RHACs are investigated: L1 adaptive controller and adaptive model predicative controller (AMPC).  For real-time implementation of L1 adaptive controller, event-triggered scheduling is applied.  The stability conditions, in terms of event threshold and allowable transmission delays, are derived, which serve as the guidance in real-time scheduling.  The AMPC is developed for constrained control systems.  It is shown that stability and feasibility of the system under AMPC can always be guaranteed under the standard assumptions for traditional min-max MPC approaches, while the AMPC algorithm enhances the control performance by efficiently reducing the size of the feasible set of the uncertainty in min-max MPC setting.  Both of the RHACs can guarantee the transient performance and steady state of the system under mechanical failures.

The work on fault diagnosis and prognosis (FDP) brings the concept of Lebesgue sampling (LS) in fault detection. A novel diagnostic philosophy of "execution only when necessary" is presented for computation cost reduction and uncertainty management. For prognosis, different from traditional approaches where the prognostic horizon is on the time axis, the proposed approach defines prognostic horizon on the state axis. With a reduced prognostic horizon, the LS-FDP naturally benefits the uncertainty management from the computational efficiency point of view. The design and implementation of LS-FDP is based on particle filtering algorithms with experimental results to verify the effectiveness of the proposed approaches.  Experiments on the Li-ion battery FDP show that, compared with periodic FDP, the LS-FDP can be 1200+ times faster without sacrificing the performance in terms of accuracy, precision, and robustness of FDP.

The RSimplex control architecture for CPS can tolerate a wide class of software failures and mechanical failures. This will greatly enhance the CPS infrastructure.  This research ensures that bene?ts of CPS technologies can be realized under realistic assumptions about automation capability and reliability.  The results of this project have been communicated in archival journal publications, conference venues and various workshops and lectures.
